column4: is it reasonable to have a main partition of 30GB, or is it too small? Does Linux software know to install on other partitions by default?
it depends on where you mount the partitions
what do you mean?
installations have no knowledge of physical disks, they'll install into /usr, what partition that is depends on what you mount there
i take you are unfamiliar with the basics of unix filesystems?
that's right
installed programs go to /usr, if you want them installed on a different partition, you mount that partition on /usr
but then I only see part of the installed software at a given time. is this true?
tell the installer to use the partition for /usr and everything will go onto that partition
if I switch /usr to another partition a month from now, all the software already installed will just "disappear"?
that's right, if you want to permanently use another parition, then you must move the existing files onto that partition
interesting.
every filesystem is mounted somewhere in the / hierarchy, there is no concept of seperate hierarchies for different devices
so I can actually move the entire installation to a new partition in this manner?
sure
but you must remember to update /etc/fstab
so that it knows what to mount and where
i'll drop by for assistance when the day to move partitions arrives.
I am a Windows developer. I discovered Ubuntu 2 month ago when developing os-indiferent software (in Python) and was amazed. Now I want to attempt a gradual switch to Ubuntu...!
well it's rather easy to move things to different partitions, just copy and update fstab
thanks
